clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city features an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
Visitors often toss coins into a famous baroque fountain for good luck.
fun_fact: About €3,000 is thrown into the Trevi Fountain each day, which is collected and donated to charity.
Rome has more than 2,000 fountains, more than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Vatican City, the world's smallest independent state, is located entirely within this city.
The Pantheon in Rome has the world's largest unreinforced concrete dome, built almost 2,000 years ago.

clues: This harbor city is known for its iconic opera house with sail-shaped roofs.
It hosted the Olympic Games in 2000 and has one of the world's most famous beaches.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House has over one million roof tiles covering its iconic sails.
Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its distinctive arch-based design.
trivia: Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world, with lifeguards featuring in a popular TV show.
The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to build, ten years longer than planned.

clues: This city sits near some of the world's most famous ancient triangular structures.
The longest river in the world flows through this ancient capital.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years.
Cairo's Al-Azhar University, founded in 970 CE, is one of the oldest universities in the world.
trivia: The city is nicknamed 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its numerous mosques.
The Egyptian Museum in Cairo contains over 120,000 ancient Egyptian artifacts.

clues: This city is known for a massive statue of Christ with outstretched arms.
It hosts the world's largest carnival celebration every year before Lent.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue was struck by lightning during a violent electrical storm in 2014, damaging one of the thumbs.
Copacabana Beach stretches for 4 kilometers and is covered with white quartz sand that doesn't get hot even on the hottest days.
trivia: The name Rio de Janeiro means 'January River,' although it's actually a bay, not a river.
The city was once the capital of Portugal when the royal family fled Napoleon's invasion in 1808.

clues: This romantic city is built on more than 100 small islands connected by canals and bridges.
Traditional gondolas are a primary form of transportation here.
fun_fact: Venice has no roads, just canals – including the Grand Canal which winds through the city in a reverse S shape.
The city is slowly sinking at a rate of about 1-2 millimeters per year.
trivia: The Venetian gondolas are asymmetrical - they're built slightly tilted to one side to counterbalance the weight of the gondolier.
Marco Polo, the famous explorer, was born in Venice in 1254.

clues: This desert city has the world's tallest building, which stands over 828 meters high.
It contains artificial islands shaped like palm trees and a map of the world.
fun_fact: Dubai has the world's only 7-star hotel, the Burj Al Arab, shaped like a sail.
The Dubai Mall is so big that it would take about 14 hours to see the entire mall if you spent just 5 minutes in each store.
trivia: The police force here drives supercars including Lamborghinis, Ferraris, and Bugattis.
Dubai has the world's largest choreographed fountain system at the base of the Burj Khalifa.

clues: This city is famous for its unfinished basilica designed by architect Antoni Gaudí.
It hosted the Summer Olympics in 1992 and is renowned for its distinctive architecture.
fun_fact: La Sagrada Familia has been under construction since 1882 and isn't expected to be completed until 2026.
Barcelona has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, most of which were designed by Antoni Gaudí.
trivia: The famous football club based here has one of the largest sports stadiums in Europe, with a capacity of 99,354.
Las Ramblas, the famous pedestrian street, was once a stream bed outside the city walls.

clues: This city has one of the most recognizable skylines, best viewed from Victoria Peak.
It was a British colony until 1997 and is known for its blend of Eastern and Western cultures.
fun_fact: Hong Kong has more skyscrapers than any other city in the world, with over 300 buildings taller than 150 meters.
The name Hong Kong means 'Fragrant Harbor' in Cantonese, referring to the incense wood trade.
trivia: Hong Kong has the world's longest outdoor covered escalator system, stretching for over 800 meters.
The Star Ferry has been carrying passengers across Victoria Harbour since 1888 and remains a popular tourist attraction.

clues: This unique city straddles two continents, divided by the Bosphorus Strait.
Once known as Constantinople, it was the capital of the Byzantine and Ottoman Empires.
fun_fact: The Grand Bazaar is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world, with over 4,000 shops.
Istanbul's Hagia Sophia served as a church for 916 years, a mosque for 481 years, and a museum for 85 years.
trivia: Tulips, which are associated with Holland, actually originated in Turkey and were exported to the Netherlands.
The city has been the capital of four empires: Roman, Byzantine, Latin, and Ottoman.

clues: This city-state is known for its cleanliness and features a hotel with an infinity pool on its roof.
Chewing gum is banned in this Southeast Asian metropolis famous for its strict laws.
fun_fact: Singapore has the world's first night zoo, the Night Safari, which houses over 2,500 animals.
The iconic Merlion statue combines a lion's head and a fish's body, representing the city's origins as a fishing village.
trivia: Singapore is one of three city-states in the world, alongside Monaco and Vatican City.
The architecture of the Marina Bay Sands hotel was inspired by a deck of cards.

clues: This coastal city sits beneath a flat-topped mountain and near where two oceans meet.
Home to a famous prison island where Nelson Mandela was held for 18 years.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has its own cloud formation known locally as the 'tablecloth' when it spills over the mountain.
Cape Town is the legislative capital of South Africa, while Pretoria is the administrative capital.
trivia: The Cape of Good Hope near this city isn't actually the southernmost point of Africa, despite popular belief.
The World Design Capital title was awarded to Cape Town in 2014, the first African city to receive this designation.

clues: This high-altitude capital was built atop an ancient Aztec city and lake.
It's one of the largest urban areas in the world and known for its historic center.
fun_fact: Mexico City is slowly sinking at a rate of about 20 centimeters per year because it was built on a lake.
The city has more museums than any other city in the world, with over 150 museums to explore.
trivia: The city's Chapultepec Park is one of the largest urban parks in the world, twice the size of New York's Central Park.
The ancient Aztec city of Tenochtitlan, upon which Mexico City was built, had advanced floating gardens called chinampas.

clues: This city has more bridges than Venice and more bicycles than people.
Famous for its narrow houses, canals, and museum dedicated to a painter who cut off his ear.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has over 165 canals with a combined length of more than 100 kilometers.
The narrowest house in Amsterdam is only 2.02 meters wide, while the narrowest house front is just 1 meter wide.
trivia: Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport is built on land that was once a lake, and it's 4.5 meters below sea level.
The Royal Palace of Amsterdam was built on 13,659 wooden piles to prevent it from sinking into the marsh.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant markets called souks and its distinctive red buildings.
It features a famous central square that transforms into an open-air food market at night.
fun_fact: The medina (old city) of Marrakech has over 1,000 alleyways, most without names, creating a natural maze.
The blue worn by the Tuareg people of the region is not just fashion – it's believed the indigo dye protects from evil spirits.
trivia: Marrakech is known as the 'Red City' due to the color of many of its buildings and walls.
The Jardin Majorelle, a stunning garden in the city, was once owned by fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent.

clues: This city is known for its medieval astronomical clock installed in 1410 that still works today.
Famous for its Charles Bridge lined with statues and its hilltop castle complex.
fun_fact: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world, covering an area of almost 70,000 square meters.
The city's famous Dancing House was inspired by the dancing skills of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.
trivia: Prague has been nicknamed 'The City of a Hundred Spires' because of its many gothic church spires.
The word 'robot' was invented in Prague by writer Karel Čapek in his 1920 play R.U.R.

clues: This city is known as the 'Paris of South America' for its European-style architecture.
Famous for tango dancing and the colorful La Boca neighborhood.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has the widest avenue in the world, 9 de Julio Avenue, which spans up to 140 meters wide.
The city has the highest concentration of theaters in the world, with over 300 theaters.
trivia: The Recoleta Cemetery in this city contains the graves of notable people including Eva Perón and Nobel Prize winners.
Buenos Aires residents are called porteños, referring to the city's status as a port city.

clues: This city combines ancient palaces with ultra-modern technology and architecture.
Known for its vibrant street food scene and pop culture that has gained global popularity.
fun_fact: Seoul has one of the world's most efficient and extensive subway systems, with free Wi-Fi throughout.
Incheon International Airport in Seoul consistently ranks as one of the world's best airports and features an indoor ice skating rink.
trivia: Seoul's Dongdaemun Design Plaza changes its facade colors by using 40,000 LED lights on its exterior.
The city has a 'Toilet Culture Park,' a museum dedicated to the history of toilets and sanitation.

clues: This former capital is known for its classical Buddhist temples and traditional wooden houses.
Famous for its geisha district and thousands of historic shrines and gardens.
fun_fact: Kyoto was spared from bombings during World War II due to its cultural significance.
The city has over 1,600 Buddhist temples and 400 Shinto shrines.
trivia: Kyoto was Japan's capital city for more than 1,000 years until 1868.
The famous Bamboo Grove in Arashiyama is actually a soundscape project, designed to be a government-recognized 'soundscape' of Japan.

clues: This city is home to the world's most expensive private residence and Bollywood film industry.
Features a distinctive harbor gateway monument that was completed in 1924.
fun_fact: Mumbai's dabbawalas deliver over 200,000 home-cooked lunches every day with an error rate of just 1 in 16 million deliveries.
The Gateway of India was built to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary to India in 1911.
trivia: Mumbai was originally seven separate islands that were reclaimed and connected over time.
Dharavi, one of Asia's largest slums, sits in contrast to the world's most expensive home, Antilia, which is worth over $1 billion.

clues: This city was divided by a famous wall from 1961 to 1989.
Known for its vibrant arts scene and a historic gate that has become a symbol of peace.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice, with over 1,700 bridges spanning its many waterways.
The Berlin Wall was 155 kilometers long, and only a small portion of it remains standing today as a memorial.
trivia: The city has three UNESCO World Heritage sites: Museum Island, the Palaces and Parks of Potsdam, and the Modernism Housing Estates.
Berlin's Tiergarten park was originally a hunting ground for the kings of Prussia.

clues: This ancient city is considered holy by three major world religions.
Its old city is divided into four quarters, each with distinct religious significance.
fun_fact: Jerusalem has been captured and recaptured 44 times throughout its history.
The Western Wall receives around one million notes placed in its cracks each year, which are collected and buried twice a year.
trivia: The city has more than 2,000 archaeological sites.
Jerusalem Stone, a pale limestone, is required by local law to be used as a building material for all structures.

clues: This city is dominated by an ancient citadel with ruins of a famous temple dedicated to Athena.
Considered the birthplace of democracy and Western civilization.
fun_fact: The Acropolis has survived for nearly 25 centuries through wars, explosions, bombardments, fires, earthquakes, and pollution.
Athens has been inhabited continuously for over 7,000 years, making it one of the oldest cities in Europe.
trivia: The modern Olympic Games were revived in Athens in 1896.
Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle all taught in Athens, helping establish it as the academic center of the ancient world.

clues: This city's full ceremonial name is the longest place name in the world at 168 letters.
Known for its ornate shrines, floating markets, and tuk-tuks.
fun_fact: Bangkok's actual name in Thai is Krung Thep Maha Nakhon, which is just a shortened version of the full ceremonial name.
The city has more than 400 temples (wats) featuring stunning architecture and Buddha images.
trivia: The city was built on a swamp, earning it the nickname 'Venice of the East' for its canals.
Bangkok is home to the world's largest solid gold Buddha statue, weighing 5.5 tons.

clues: This city was built on swampland by Peter the Great as a 'window to Europe.'
Known for its canal network and the Winter Palace, which houses a famous art museum.
fun_fact: The Hermitage Museum has so many exhibits that if you spent one minute looking at each item, it would take 11 years to see everything.
During summer, the city experiences 'White Nights' when the sun barely sets, and the sky remains light even at midnight.
trivia: Saint Petersburg has changed its name three times: it was called Petrograd from 1914-1924 and Leningrad from 1924-1991.
The city contains over 340 bridges, many of which are raised at night to allow ships to pass through the Neva River.

clues: This Caribbean capital is known for its vintage American cars and colorful colonial architecture.
Famous for its cigars, rum, and the historic district of Habana Vieja.
fun_fact: Many of Havana's vintage cars are from the 1950s, before the U.S. embargo, and are still running due to ingenious repairs.
The city's Capitol building is modeled after the U.S. Capitol but is slightly taller, wider, and more richly adorned.
trivia: Ernest Hemingway lived near Havana for 20 years and wrote 'The Old Man and the Sea' there.
El Floridita, one of Hemingway's favorite bars, claims to be the 'Cradle of the Daiquiri' cocktail.

clues: This city's famous river is crossed by more than 20 bridges, including the Ha'penny Bridge.
Home to a famous dark stout beer that's been brewed since 1759.
fun_fact: The Guinness Storehouse is Ireland's number one tourist attraction, receiving over 1.7 million visitors annually.
Phoenix Park in Dublin is the largest enclosed city park in any European capital, and it's home to a herd of wild deer.
trivia: Dublin has produced many renowned literary figures including James Joyce, Oscar Wilde, and Samuel Beckett.
The Book of Kells, an illuminated manuscript from around 800 AD, is housed in Trinity College Library.

clues: This city is famous for its coffee houses, classical music, and Spanish Riding School.
Once the capital of the Habsburg Empire and home to many famous composers.
fun_fact: Vienna has been named the world's most livable city multiple times in quality of life surveys.
The Wiener Riesenrad is one of the oldest still-operating Ferris wheels in the world, built in 1897.
trivia: Vienna's Central Cemetery has more than 2.5 million tombs, including those of Beethoven, Schubert, and Strauss.
The city's Schönbrunn Palace has 1,441 rooms and was the summer residence of the Habsburg emperors.

clues: This northerly capital is powered almost entirely by geothermal energy.
The world's northernmost capital of a sovereign state, known for its colorful houses.
fun_fact: Reykjavik translates to 'Smoky Bay' due to the steam that rises from its many hot springs.
During winter, the city averages just 4 hours of daylight, while in summer, the sun barely sets.
trivia: Reykjavik's Hallgrímskirkja church took 41 years to build and its design was inspired by basalt lava columns.
The city has no mosquitoes, thanks to its climate conditions.

clues: This city is built on seven hills and features a castle atop an extinct volcano.
Known for its annual arts festival and the Royal Mile connecting two royal residences.
fun_fact: Edinburgh has more listed buildings than anywhere in the world, with 4,500 listed buildings in the city center alone.
The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the world's largest arts festival, with over 55,000 performances in a typical year.
trivia: The real-life inspiration for Harry Potter characters Tom Riddle and Professor McGonagall are buried in Greyfriars Kirkyard cemetery.
Edinburgh was the first city in the world to have its own fire service, established in 1824.

clues: This city is known for its iconic red suspension bridge and cable cars.
Built on more than 40 hills and famous for its fog and Victorian houses.
fun_fact: The Golden Gate Bridge's color is officially called 'International Orange' and was chosen for its visibility in fog.
Alcatraz was a federal prison from 1934-1963, and despite numerous escape attempts, no prisoner is confirmed to have successfully escaped.
trivia: The city's Lombard Street is known as the 'crookedest street in the world' with eight sharp turns.
San Francisco's cable cars are the only mobile National Monument in the United States.

clues: This island destination features white buildings with blue domes perched on cliffs.
Known for spectacular sunsets over its caldera formed by a massive volcanic eruption.
fun_fact: The island's official name is Thira, and it's actually a group of islands forming a ring around an underwater volcano.
Some believe that Santorini might be the location of the lost city of Atlantis described by Plato.
trivia: The island's unique architectural style features cave houses built into the volcanic rock.
Santorini has beaches with different colored sand – black, red, and white – due to its volcanic nature.

clues: This ancient city sits high in the Andes Mountains and was built by the Inca civilization.
Discovered by American explorer Hiram Bingham in 1911 after being hidden for centuries.
fun_fact: Machu Picchu was built without the use of wheels, iron tools, or mortar – the stones fit so perfectly that not even a knife blade can fit between them.
The site was never found by Spanish conquistadors and thus was one of the most well-preserved Inca sites when discovered.
trivia: The citadel contains more than 100 separate flights of stairs, most of which were carved from a single slab of stone.
The name means 'Old Mountain' or 'Old Peak' in the Quechua language.

clues: This ancient city is carved into rose-colored stone and accessed through a narrow canyon.
Featured in 'Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade' and often called the 'Rose City'.
fun_fact: Petra was built by the Nabataeans, who carved the city out of solid rock and created an ingenious water management system in the desert.
The Treasury (Al-Khazneh), Petra's most famous structure, is believed to have been a mausoleum.
trivia: Petra was unknown to the Western world until 1812 when it was discovered by Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt.
Only about 15% of the ancient city has been excavated, with the rest still hidden underground.

clues: This city's famous central square is home to a colorful cathedral with onion domes.
The Kremlin, a fortified complex in this city, serves as the official residence of the country's president.
fun_fact: Moscow's Metro stations are like underground palaces, decorated with chandeliers, sculptures, and mosaics.
St. Basil's Cathedral was allegedly built by Ivan the Terrible, who then blinded the architect so he couldn't build anything more beautiful.
trivia: Moscow has the highest number of billionaire residents of any city in the world.
The city's Red Square isn't named for communism or the color of its bricks – 'red' in old Russian also meant 'beautiful'.

clues: This coastal city is surrounded by massive stone walls dating from the 12th century.
Known as the 'Pearl of the Adriatic' and used as a filming location for a popular fantasy TV series.
fun_fact: Dubrovnik's walls are among the most well-preserved city fortifications in Europe, stretching for nearly 2 kilometers.
The city was an independent republic called Ragusa for over 700 years until Napoleon conquered it in 1806.
trivia: King's Landing in Game of Thrones was primarily filmed in this UNESCO World Heritage city.
Dubrovnik was severely damaged by an earthquake in 1667 and again during the Croatian War of Independence in the 1990s, but has been meticulously restored.

clues: This North American city has a distinctly European feel with cobblestone streets and fortified walls.
Home to a famous ice hotel that is rebuilt every winter and a grand château-style hotel.
fun_fact: Quebec City is the only walled city north of Mexico in North America, with walls that stretch for 4.6 kilometers.
The Château Frontenac holds the Guinness World Record for being the most photographed hotel in the world.
trivia: Old Quebec (Vieux-Québec) is a UNESCO World Heritage site and the historic district of the city.
The city hosts the world's largest winter carnival, featuring ice sculptures, parades, and winter sports.

clues: This high-altitude city was once the capital of the Inca Empire.
Serves as the gateway to Machu Picchu and features impressive stone walls built by the Incas.
fun_fact: Cusco was designed in the shape of a puma, a sacred animal to the Incas.
The city sits at an elevation of 3,399 meters (11,152 feet), making it one of the highest major cities in the world.
trivia: The name Cusco means 'navel' or 'center' in Quechua, as the Incas considered it the center of the world.
Many of Cusco's colonial buildings were built on foundations of Inca structures that survived a major earthquake in 1650.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant markets called souks and its distinctive red buildings.
It features a famous central square that transforms into an open-air food market at night.
fun_fact: The medina (old city) of Marrakech has over 1,000 alleyways, most without names, creating a natural maze.
The city's walls, which stretch for 19 kilometers around the medina, were built in the 12th century.
trivia: Marrakech is known as the 'Red City' due to the color of many of its buildings and walls.
The Jardin Majorelle, a stunning garden in the city, was once owned by fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent.

clues: This city is built on 14 islands connected by 57 bridges.
Home to the museum of a famous pop group that won Eurovision with 'Waterloo'.
fun_fact: Stockholm's subway system is known as the world's longest art gallery, with over 90 stations decorated with sculptures, mosaics, and paintings.
The Nobel Prizes are awarded in this city every year on December 10, the anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death.
trivia: Stockholm's Vasa Museum houses a nearly fully intact 17th-century ship that sank on its maiden voyage.
The city's old town, Gamla Stan, dates back to the 13th century and is one of the best-preserved medieval city centers in Europe.

clues: This capital city sits in a valley surrounded by the Himalayan mountains.
Known for its ancient temples, including one with eyes painted on all four sides of its tower.
fun_fact: Kathmandu has the densest concentration of UNESCO World Heritage Sites of any city in the world.
The city's Durbar Square contains more than 50 temples and palaces built between the 12th and 18th centuries.
trivia: Swayambhunath, known as the 'Monkey Temple,' is one of the oldest religious sites in Nepal and is home to hundreds of monkeys considered holy.
The city's name derives from an ancient structure called Kasthamandap, which was built from the wood of a single tree.

clues: This hilly coastal capital is famous for its yellow trams that navigate steep streets.
Known for melancholic fado music and colorful tiles decorating many buildings.
fun_fact: Lisbon is built on seven hills, similar to Rome.
The city was almost completely destroyed by an earthquake, tsunami, and fire in 1755.
trivia: Lisbon's Vasco da Gama Bridge is one of the longest bridges in Europe at nearly 17 kilometers.
The city's São Jorge Castle has stood on a hilltop overlooking the city since the 11th century.

clues: This city features a central lake with a temple on an island reached by a red bridge.
Known for its Old Quarter with 36 streets named after the trades once conducted there.
fun_fact: Hanoi's Temple of Literature was built in 1070 and is home to Vietnam's first national university.
The city's train street features a railway that runs so close to buildings that residents must move their belongings when trains pass.
trivia: Hanoi has been Vietnam's capital for over a thousand years, with a brief interruption during the French colonial period.
The city's Hoan Kiem Lake contains a rare species of giant softshell turtle that is nearly extinct.

clues: This medieval city is crisscrossed by canals and often called the 'Venice of the North'.
Famous for its cobblestone streets, Gothic architecture, and Belgian chocolate shops.
fun_fact: Bruges' historic city center is a UNESCO World Heritage site and has remained largely unchanged for centuries.
The city has more than 80 bridges spanning its canals.
trivia: Bruges is home to the only sculpture by Michelangelo outside of Italy, a Madonna and Child in the Church of Our Lady.
The Belfry of Bruges contains a carillon with 47 bells that are still played manually.

clues: This coastal city sits beneath a flat-topped mountain and near where two oceans meet.
Home to a famous prison island where Nelson Mandela was held for 18 years.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has its own cloud formation known locally as the 'tablecloth' when it spills over the mountain.
The city is located near the meeting point of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
trivia: Cape Town was founded in 1652 as a supply station for Dutch ships sailing to East Africa, India, and the Far East.
The city's Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden is considered one of the most beautiful gardens in Africa.

clues: This unique city straddles two continents, divided by the Bosphorus Strait.
Once known as Constantinople, it was the capital of the Byzantine and Ottoman Empires.
fun_fact: The Grand Bazaar is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world, with over 4,000 shops.
The Hagia Sophia was the world's largest cathedral for nearly a thousand years until the Seville Cathedral was completed.
trivia: Istanbul has been the capital of four empires: Roman, Byzantine, Latin, and Ottoman.
The city was renamed from Constantinople to Istanbul officially in 1930, although the name Istanbul had been in common use for centuries.

clues: This windy capital city is located at the southwestern tip of New Zealand's North Island.
Known for its red cable car that climbs from the city center to the botanic garden.
fun_fact: Wellington is the southernmost capital city in the world.
The city is built on an active geological fault line and experiences about 1,500 earthquakes each year.
trivia: Wellington is home to Weta Workshop, where special effects for The Lord of the Rings and other films were created.
The city's parliament building is nicknamed 'The Beehive' due to its distinctive shape.

clues: This bilingual city features an extensive underground city used during harsh winters.
Known for its historic old town with cobblestone streets and the second-largest French-speaking population after Paris.
fun_fact: Montreal has more restaurants per capita than any other city in North America.
The city's underground pedestrian network, RÉSO, spans over 32 kilometers and connects buildings, shopping centers, and metro stations.
trivia: Montreal hosted the 1976 Summer Olympics, which featured the tallest inclined tower in the world.
The city was originally called Ville-Marie ('City of Mary') and was founded as a missionary colony in 1642.

clues: This Italian city is known as the 'Cradle of the Renaissance' and home to Michelangelo's David.
Famous for its dome-topped cathedral and the Ponte Vecchio bridge lined with shops.
fun_fact: The Florence Cathedral's dome, designed by Brunelleschi, was the largest dome in the world until modern times and was built without scaffolding.
The city was the birthplace of many Renaissance masters including Leonardo da Vinci and Botticelli.
trivia: Florence's Uffizi Gallery is one of the oldest and most famous art museums in the world.
The historic center of Florence is a UNESCO World Heritage site and contains 600 years of architectural masterpieces.

clues: This desert city has the world's tallest building, which stands over 828 meters high.
It contains artificial islands shaped like palm trees and a map of the world.
fun_fact: Dubai has the world's only 7-star hotel, the Burj Al Arab, shaped like a sail.
The city has the world's largest choreographed fountain system at the base of the Burj Khalifa.
trivia: Dubai has the world's largest indoor theme park, IMG Worlds of Adventure.
In just 50 years, Dubai transformed from a small fishing village to one of the most futuristic cities in the world.

clues: This coastal city is consistently ranked as one of the world's most livable cities.
Surrounded by mountains and water, it's one of the few places where you can ski and sail on the same day.
fun_fact: Vancouver's Stanley Park is larger than New York's Central Park at 405 hectares (1,001 acres).
The city has the longest uninterrupted waterfront path in the world, the 28-kilometer Seawall.
trivia: Vancouver is home to the world's first steam-powered clock, located in Gastown.
The city is nicknamed 'Hollywood North' because it's the third-largest film production center in North America.

clues: This city sits near some of the world's most famous ancient triangular structures.
The longest river in the world flows through this ancient capital.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years.
Cairo's Al-Azhar University, founded in 970 CE, is one of the oldest universities in the world.
trivia: The city is nicknamed 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its numerous mosques.
The Egyptian Museum in Cairo contains over 120,000 ancient Egyptian artifacts, including treasures from Tutankhamun's tomb.

clues: This capital city sits in a valley surrounded by the Himalayan mountains.
Known for its ancient temples, including one with eyes painted on all four sides of its tower.
fun_fact: Kathmandu has the densest concentration of UNESCO World Heritage Sites of any city in the world.
The city's Durbar Square contains more than 50 temples and palaces built between the 12th and 18th centuries.
trivia: Swayambhunath, known as the 'Monkey Temple,' is one of the oldest religious sites in Nepal and is home to hundreds of monkeys considered holy.
The city's name derives from an ancient structure called Kasthamandap, which was built from the wood of a single tree.

clues: This colorful Caribbean port city is surrounded by massive stone walls built to defend against pirates.
Known for its well-preserved colonial old town with cobblestone streets and vibrant buildings.
fun_fact: Cartagena's walls took 200 years to complete and are among the most complete and best preserved in South America.
The city was named after Cartagena, Spain, which itself was named after Carthage in North Africa.
trivia: Cartagena was a major port for shipping gold and other treasures from the New World to Spain.
The city's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site and was the setting for Gabriel García Márquez's novel 'Love in the Time of Cholera'.

clues: This island city is known for its historic Stone Town district and spice plantations.
Once a major center of the spice and slave trades in East Africa.
fun_fact: Stone Town has 546 distinctive carved doorways, each with a unique pattern that often indicates the original owner's occupation or status.
Freddie Mercury, the lead vocalist of Queen, was born in this city.
trivia: Zanzibar briefly became an independent country after British colonial rule before joining with Tanganyika to form Tanzania.
The city was once the capital of the Sultanate of Oman when the sultan moved his court there in the 19th century.

clues: This resort town on New Zealand's South Island is known as the 'Adventure Capital of the World'.
Surrounded by mountains and on the shore of a Z-shaped lake.
fun_fact: Queenstown is home to the world's first commercial bungee jumping operation, established in 1988.
The town was named 'Queenstown' because it was 'fit for Queen Victoria'.
trivia: Many scenes from The Lord of the Rings trilogy were filmed in the landscapes surrounding this town.
Despite its reputation for extreme sports, Queenstown was originally a gold mining town in the 1860s.

clues: This Baltic capital is known for its well-preserved medieval old town with city walls and towers.
Once a major center of the Hanseatic League, a medieval trading alliance.
fun_fact: Tallinn's Old Town is one of the best-preserved medieval cities in Europe and is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city is often referred to as the Silicon Valley of Europe due to its high number of tech startups per capita.
trivia: Tallinn was the first capital city to offer free public transportation to all its residents.
The city's Town Hall Square has been a marketplace for over 800 years and hosts one of Europe's oldest continuously running pharmacies.

clues: This city is the highest administrative capital in the world at over 3,600 meters above sea level.
Known for its unique cable car system that serves as public transportation through the mountainous terrain.
fun_fact: La Paz has the world's highest and longest urban cable car network, called Mi Teleférico.
The city is built in a canyon created by the La Paz River, giving it a bowl-like appearance surrounded by the Andes.
trivia: La Paz's international airport, El Alto, is the highest international airport in the world at 4,061 meters.
While La Paz is the seat of government, Sucre is actually the constitutional capital of Bolivia.

clues: This mountain town is famous for its buildings painted in various shades of blue.
Located in the Rif Mountains of northwest Morocco, it was founded in 1471.
fun_fact: The blue walls were originally painted in the 1930s by Jewish refugees, as blue represents the sky and heaven in Judaism.
The city's name comes from the Berber word for horns, 'Ech Chaouen,' referring to the mountain peaks visible above the town.
trivia: Chefchaouen was once a forbidden city for Christians, who would face the death penalty if caught entering.
The city is known for its high-quality handmade goods, especially woven blankets and wool garments.

clues: This UNESCO World Heritage city sits at the confluence of the Mekong and Nam Khan rivers.
Known for its well-preserved colonial architecture and Buddhist temples with golden roofs.
fun_fact: Every morning at dawn, hundreds of monks walk through the streets collecting alms in a tradition called Tak Bat.
The city was the royal capital of the Kingdom of Laos until the communist takeover in 1975.
trivia: Luang Prabang's name means 'Royal Buddha Image' after a Buddha statue brought to the city in the 14th century.
The city is surrounded by waterfalls, including the multi-tiered Kuang Si Falls with striking turquoise pools.

clues: This colorful port city is built on dozens of steep hillsides overlooking the Pacific Ocean.
Known for its funiculars, street art, and bohemian culture.
fun_fact: Valparaíso has 42 hills, each with its own distinct neighborhood and character.
The city's historic funicular elevators, built in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, are considered national monuments.
trivia: Valparaíso's historic quarter is a UNESCO World Heritage site, noted for its improvised urban design adapted to the difficult terrain.
The poet Pablo Neruda had one of his three houses here, which is now a museum called La Sebastiana.

clues: This city serves as the gateway to the ruins of a vast stone temple complex.
Known for its proximity to temples with tree roots growing over ancient stone structures.
fun_fact: The name Siem Reap means 'Defeat of Siam' (now Thailand), referring to a Cambodian victory over the Thai army.
The city was nearly abandoned for centuries until the temples of Angkor were 'rediscovered' by French explorers in the 1860s.
trivia: Siem Reap is home to Angkor Wat, the largest religious monument in the world.
The city has a vibrant night market and Pub Street area that contrasts with the ancient temples nearby.

clues: This Alpine city is the birthplace of Mozart and where 'The Sound of Music' was filmed.
Known for its baroque architecture and fortress overlooking the old town.
fun_fact: Salzburg means 'Salt Fortress,' named for the barges that carried salt on the Salzach River, the source of the city's historical wealth.
The Salzburg Festival, one of the world's most prestigious music festivals, has been held annually since 1920.
trivia: Salzburg's old town is a UNESCO World Heritage site and one of the best-preserved city centers north of the Alps.
The Hohensalzburg Fortress is one of the largest medieval castles in Europe and has never been captured by foreign enemies.

clues: This city in a valley of the Andes was once known as the most dangerous city in the world but has transformed into an innovative urban center.
Known for its cable car public transportation system and outdoor escalators connecting hillside neighborhoods.
fun_fact: Medellin is known as the 'City of Eternal Spring' due to its pleasant year-round temperature averaging 22°C (72°F).
The city won the Innovative City of the Year award in 2013, beating out New York and Tel Aviv.
trivia: Medellin's outdoor escalators in Comuna 13 have helped transform one of the city's most violent neighborhoods into a tourist attraction.
The city hosts the annual Flower Festival (Feria de las Flores), where silleteros carry elaborate flower arrangements on their backs.

clues: This city has the oldest university in the world and a medina with 9,000 narrow streets and alleys.
Known for its ancient leather tanneries where methods have remained unchanged for centuries.
fun_fact: The medina of Fez is believed to be the world's largest car-free urban area and is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The University of Al Quaraouiyine, founded in 859 AD, is recognized by UNESCO as the oldest continuously operating university in the world.
trivia: The blue dye used in the city's famous pottery comes from cobalt mined in the nearby mountains.
Fez hats (the red cylindrical hats with tassels) were originally manufactured in this city before becoming popular worldwide.

clues: This small South Pacific island is famous for its overwater bungalows and turquoise lagoon.
Dominated by two extinct volcano peaks and surrounded by a barrier reef and motus (small islands).
fun_fact: The name Bora Bora actually comes from the Tahitian pronunciation of 'Pora Pora', meaning 'first born'.
During World War II, the United States used the island as a supply base and built an airstrip that brought the first non-sailing vessels to the island.
trivia: The water in Bora Bora's lagoon is home to manta rays with wingspans of up to 5 meters and reef sharks that pose no threat to humans.
There are no poisonous snakes or insects on the island, making it one of the safest tropical destinations.

clues: This village on the northwestern tip of Santorini is famous for its blue-domed churches and sunset views.
Known for its white-washed buildings built into the cliffside overlooking a caldera.
fun_fact: Oia has no natural water source – all fresh water must be imported or collected from rainfall.
The village's iconic windmills once played a crucial role in the island's economy by grinding grain into flour.
trivia: Oia is one of the most photographed locations in the world and appears on countless postcards and travel magazines.
Houses in the village were traditionally built with volcanic stone, making them natural air conditioners – cool in summer and warm in winter.

clues: This desert town is known for its red rock formations and is considered a spiritual vortex site.
Located in Arizona, it's known for its vibrant arts community and outdoor recreational activities.
fun_fact: Sedona was named after Sedona Miller Schnebly, the wife of the city's first postmaster, making it one of few cities named after a woman.
The area's distinctive red rocks get their color from iron oxide (rust) coating the sandstone.
trivia: Sedona has strict building codes to preserve its natural beauty, including limits on building heights and requirements that structures blend with the natural surroundings.
The town has no streetlights to preserve the dark sky for stargazing, earning it the designation as an International Dark Sky Community.

clues: This religious monument is the largest of its kind in the world and appears on its nation's flag.
Built in the 12th century, it was initially a Hindu temple that gradually transformed into a Buddhist one.
fun_fact: Angkor Wat is aligned with the spring equinox so that when viewed from the main entrance, the sun rises directly over the central tower.
The stone blocks used to build this massive complex were quarried more than 50 kilometers away and transported by a combination of elephants, rafts, and human labor.
trivia: The site was largely abandoned in the 15th century but never completely forgotten by locals, making it different from many 'lost' ancient cities.
The walls of Angkor Wat contain nearly a kilometer of intricate bas-relief carvings depicting historical events and mythological stories.

clues: This natural wonder is the world's largest coral reef system, stretching over 2,300 kilometers.
Visible from space, it contains thousands of reefs and hundreds of islands off Australia's east coast.
fun_fact: The Great Barrier Reef is home to about 10% of all fish species in the world, with over 1,500 different species.
This living structure is actually composed of billions of tiny organisms called coral polyps that build calcium carbonate skeletons.
trivia: Despite covering a vast area, coral reefs only make up about 0.1% of the ocean's surface but support 25% of all marine species.
The Great Barrier Reef is between 6,000 and 8,000 years old in its current form, but the reef structure is up to 20 million years old.

clues: This vast ecosystem is famous for its annual migration of over 1.5 million wildebeest and 200,000 zebras.
The name comes from the Maasai language meaning 'endless plains' and spans 30,000 square kilometers.
fun_fact: The Serengeti hosts the largest terrestrial mammal migration in the world, which follows a clockwise pattern covering about 800 kilometers.
Acacia trees in the Serengeti have evolved a defense system where they produce a toxic substance when giraffes begin feeding on them and release ethylene gas to warn nearby trees.
trivia: The Serengeti ecosystem is one of the oldest on Earth, with its essential vegetation and climate remaining largely unchanged for at least a million years.
While lions are the region's top predators, the park is also home to the 'big five': lions, leopards, elephants, buffalo, and rhinoceros.

clues: This ancient city sits high in the Andes Mountains and was built by the Inca civilization.
Discovered by American explorer Hiram Bingham in 1911 after being hidden for centuries.
fun_fact: Machu Picchu was built without the use of wheels, iron tools, or mortar – the stones fit so perfectly that not even a knife blade can fit between them.
The site was never found by Spanish conquistadors and thus was one of the most well-preserved Inca sites when discovered.
trivia: The citadel contains more than 100 separate flights of stairs, most of which were carved from a single slab of stone.
Machu Picchu is divided into two sectors: agricultural and urban, with about 200 buildings arranged in the urban sector.

clues: This island destination features white buildings with blue domes perched on cliffs.
Known for spectacular sunsets over its caldera formed by a massive volcanic eruption.
fun_fact: The island's official name is Thira, and it's actually a group of islands forming a ring around an underwater volcano.
Some believe that Santorini might be the location of the lost city of Atlantis described by Plato.
trivia: The island's unique architectural style features cave houses built into the volcanic rock.
Santorini's volcanic soil creates unique agricultural products, including white eggplants, cherry tomatoes, and wine from Assyrtiko grapes.

clues: This picturesque alpine village sits between a crystal-clear lake and towering mountains.
So beautiful that China built a full-scale replica of the entire town.
fun_fact: Hallstatt is so small that bodies in the cemetery were dug up after 10-15 years to make room for new burials, with the skulls painted and displayed in the Bone House.
The town is home to the world's oldest salt mine, with evidence of mining dating back to 5000 BC.
trivia: The town gives its name to the Hallstatt culture, an early Iron Age culture in Europe (800-400 BC).
Hallstatt can only be reached by boat across the lake or through a small mountain road, as there was no road access until the late 19th century.

clues: This ancient city is carved into rose-colored stone and accessed through a narrow canyon.
Featured in 'Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade' and often called the 'Rose City'.
fun_fact: Petra was built by the Nabataeans, who carved the city out of solid rock and created an ingenious water management system in the desert.
The Treasury (Al-Khazneh), Petra's most famous structure, is believed to have been a mausoleum.
trivia: Petra was unknown to the Western world until 1812 when it was discovered by Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt.
The site's elaborate water system included dams, cisterns, and ceramic pipes that allowed the city to thrive despite receiving less than 15 centimeters of rain annually.

clues: This former capital is known for its classical Buddhist temples and traditional wooden houses.
Famous for its geisha district and thousands of historic shrines and gardens.
fun_fact: Kyoto was spared from bombings during World War II due to its cultural significance.
The city has over 1,600 Buddhist temples and 400 Shinto shrines.
trivia: Kyoto was Japan's capital city for more than 1,000 years until 1868.
The Gion district is one of the few places where you can still see geiko (Kyoto's term for geisha) and maiko (apprentice geiko) performing traditional arts.

clues: This massive defensive structure stretches over 21,000 kilometers across northern China.
Built over several dynasties, the most famous sections date from the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).
fun_fact: Contrary to popular belief, this structure is not visible from space with the naked eye, as confirmed by numerous astronauts.
The mortar used in some sections includes sticky rice, which contributed to its durability over the centuries.
trivia: Only about 8% of the original wall from the Ming Dynasty remains intact today due to natural erosion and human destruction.
The wall wasn't a single continuous structure but a network of walls built by different dynasties for various purposes.

clues: This ancient city contains over 2,000 Buddhist temples and pagodas spread across a vast plain.
Known for hot air balloon rides at dawn that offer spectacular views of the temple-studded landscape.
fun_fact: At its peak between the 11th and 13th centuries, Bagan had over 10,000 Buddhist temples, pagodas, and monasteries.
Many of the temples were damaged in a 2016 earthquake, but careful restoration efforts are ongoing to preserve this archaeological treasure.
trivia: Despite its historical significance, Bagan only became a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2019 after political changes in Myanmar.
The temples of Bagan were built using millions of bricks that had to be individually fired and transported to the site.

clues: This region is famous for its 'fairy chimney' rock formations and cave dwellings carved into soft volcanic stone.
Known for colorful hot air balloons that float over its unique landscape at sunrise.
fun_fact: Early Christians in Cappadocia built underground cities that could shelter thousands of people, with ventilation systems, wells, and even wineries.
The region's distinctive landscape was formed by volcanic eruptions millions of years ago, followed by erosion.
trivia: Some of the underground cities in Cappadocia extend eight levels below ground and could shelter up to 20,000 people during times of persecution.
The region's name comes from Persian, meaning 'land of beautiful horses,' as the area was famous for horse breeding in ancient times.

clues: This Caribbean capital is known for its vintage American cars and colorful colonial architecture.
Famous for its cigars, rum, and the historic district of Habana Vieja.
fun_fact: Many of Havana's vintage cars are from the 1950s, before the U.S. embargo, and are still running due to ingenious repairs.
The city's Capitol building is modeled after the U.S. Capitol but is slightly taller, wider, and more richly adorned.
trivia: Ernest Hemingway lived near Havana for 20 years and wrote 'The Old Man and the Sea' there.
El Floridita, one of Hemingway's favorite bars, claims to be the 'Cradle of the Daiquiri' cocktail.

clues: This massive geological formation is 446 kilometers long and up to 29 kilometers wide.
Carved by the Colorado River over millions of years, its walls reveal 2 billion years of Earth's history.
fun_fact: The Grand Canyon is deep enough to fit 20 Eiffel Towers stacked on top of each other.
Temperature differences between the rim and the bottom of the canyon can exceed 25 degrees Celsius (45 degrees Fahrenheit).
trivia: Despite its massive size, the Grand Canyon is neither the deepest nor the widest canyon in the world, but it's unmatched in its combination of size, depth, and exposed colorful rock layers.
The canyon contains nearly 1,000 caves, but only 335 have been documented, and fewer than 10 are open to the public.

clues: This northerly capital is powered almost entirely by geothermal energy.
The world's northernmost capital of a sovereign state, known for its colorful houses.
fun_fact: Reykjavik translates to 'Smoky Bay' due to the steam that rises from its many hot springs.
During winter, the city averages just 4 hours of daylight, while in summer, the sun barely sets.
trivia: Reykjavik's Hallgrímskirkja church took 41 years to build and its design was inspired by basalt lava columns.
The city has no mosquitoes, thanks to its climate conditions.

clues: This mountain town sits within Canada's oldest national park in the Rocky Mountains.
Known for its turquoise lakes, including one named for a glacial flour that gives it an emerald color.
fun_fact: Banff was established in 1885 after railway workers discovered hot springs in the area, making it Canada's first national park.
The town is named after Banffshire, Scotland, the birthplace of one of the directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway.
trivia: Banff National Park spans 6,641 square kilometers and is part of the Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Lake Louise, near Banff, gets its distinctive emerald color from rock flour (fine particles of rock) carried in the glacial meltwater.

clues: This coastal city is surrounded by massive stone walls dating from the 12th century.
Known as the 'Pearl of the Adriatic' and used as a filming location for a popular fantasy TV series.
fun_fact: Dubrovnik's walls are among the most well-preserved city fortifications in Europe, stretching for nearly 2 kilometers.
The city was an independent republic called Ragusa for over 700 years until Napoleon conquered it in 1806.
trivia: King's Landing in Game of Thrones was primarily filmed in this UNESCO World Heritage city.
Dubrovnik was severely damaged by an earthquake in 1667 and again during the Croatian War of Independence in the 1990s, but has been meticulously restored.

clues: This massive waterfall system consists of 275 falls along 2.7 kilometers of a river border.
The name means 'big water' in the indigenous Guarani language, and it's wider than Victoria Falls and taller than Niagara Falls.
fun_fact: When Eleanor Roosevelt saw these falls, she reportedly exclaimed, 'Poor Niagara!'
One of the most impressive sections is the Devil's Throat, a U-shaped cliff that marks the border between Argentina and Brazil, where water drops 80 meters.
trivia: The falls are shared by two UNESCO World Heritage Sites: Iguazú National Park in Argentina and Iguaçu National Park in Brazil.
Iguazu Falls is surrounded by one of the few remaining inland rainforests in South America, home to over 2,000 plant species.

clues: This waterfall creates the world's largest curtain of falling water during wet season.
Known locally as 'The Smoke That Thunders' due to the spray and noise it produces.
fun_fact: Victoria Falls is neither the highest nor the widest waterfall in the world, but it is classified as the largest based on its combined width of 1,708 meters and height of 108 meters.
During the full moon, a lunar rainbow or 'moonbow' can be seen in the spray of the falls, a rare phenomenon.
trivia: The falls were named by explorer David Livingstone in honor of Queen Victoria in 1855, though they had been known to local peoples for thousands of years.
Devil's Pool, a natural infinity pool at the edge of the falls, allows swimmers to look over the edge during the dry season when water levels are lower.

clues: This romantic city is built on more than 100 small islands connected by canals and bridges.
Traditional gondolas are a primary form of transportation here.
fun_fact: Venice has no roads, just canals – including the Grand Canal which winds through the city in a reverse S shape.
The city is slowly sinking at a rate of about 1-2 millimeters per year.
trivia: The Venetian gondolas are asymmetrical - they're built slightly tilted to one side to counterbalance the weight of the gondolier.
Marco Polo, the famous explorer, was born in Venice in 1254.

clues: This iconic symmetrical volcano is Japan's highest peak at 3,776 meters.
A sacred site in Japanese culture and a popular subject in art, including the famous '36 Views' woodblock print series.
fun_fact: Mount Fuji last erupted in 1707-1708, covering Tokyo (then called Edo) in ash up to several inches thick.
The mountain is actually three separate volcanoes stacked on top of each other: Komitake at the bottom, Kofuji in the middle, and Fuji at the top.
trivia: The mountain has been a pilgrimage site for centuries, and each year thousands of climbers ascend to the summit.
Mount Fuji appears in Japan's oldest poetry anthology from the 8th century and has inspired artists and poets for over a millennium.

clues: This prehistoric monument consists of a ring of standing stones, each around 4 meters high and 2.1 meters wide.
Built in several stages between 3000 BC and 1500 BC, its purpose remains a mystery.
fun_fact: The bluestones used in the monument weigh up to 4 tons each and were transported from Wales, nearly 240 kilometers away, without modern technology.
During the summer solstice, the sun rises behind the Heel Stone and its first rays shine into the center of the monument.
trivia: Stonehenge is aligned with the movements of the sun, and some theories suggest it was used as an astronomical observatory.
The site was used for burial from its earliest beginnings, with at least 200 individuals buried there during its first phase.

clues: This nation consists of 26 atolls and over 1,000 coral islands in the Indian Ocean.
Known for overwater bungalows and being the world's lowest country with an average ground level of 1.5 meters above sea level.
fun_fact: The Maldives is the flattest country on Earth, with no point more than 2.4 meters above sea level.
In 2009, the government held an underwater cabinet meeting to highlight the threat of climate change and rising sea levels to the nation.
trivia: The Maldives was the first country to adopt a state law banning the import of non-biodegradable plastic bags in 2009.
The country is the smallest in Asia in terms of both land area and population.

clues: This glacially-fed lake in Banff National Park is known for its striking turquoise blue color.
Surrounded by the Valley of the Ten Peaks, it once appeared on the Canadian twenty-dollar bill.
fun_fact: The lake's distinctive blue color comes from light refracting off rock flour (glacier silt) suspended in the water.
Despite its fame, the lake is only half the size of its neighbor, Lake Louise, and is only accessible by road for about four months of the year due to avalanche risk.
trivia: The viewpoint overlooking Moraine Lake is called the 'Twenty Dollar View' because it was featured on Canadian currency from 1969 to 1979.
The lake reaches its crest in late June, when snowmelt from the mountains fills the basin to its peak.

clues: This city sits at an elevation of 3,656 meters and is home to the massive Potala Palace.
The traditional seat of the Dalai Lama and the capital of the Tibet Autonomous Region of China.
fun_fact: The Potala Palace has 13 stories containing over 1,000 rooms, 10,000 shrines, and about 200,000 statues.
Due to the high altitude, Lhasa receives among the highest average sunlight hours (3,000) of any city in the world.
trivia: Lhasa means 'Place of the Gods' in Tibetan, and the city has been a center of Buddhism for centuries.
Until the early 20th century, very few foreigners had ever seen Lhasa, earning it the nickname 'The Forbidden City'.

clues: This ancient Mayan city features a step pyramid known as El Castillo or the Temple of Kukulcan.
During the spring and fall equinoxes, the pyramid creates the illusion of a serpent slithering down its side.
fun_fact: The main pyramid was built with specific astronomical alignments – it has 365 steps (one for each day of the year) and 52 panels (representing the 52-year cycle in the Mayan calendar).
If you clap your hands at the base of El Castillo, the sound echoes back as the chirp of a quetzal bird, which was sacred to the Maya.
trivia: Chichen Itza contains one of the largest ball courts in ancient Mesoamerica, where players had to hit a rubber ball through stone hoops using only their hips.
The site's Sacred Cenote (natural sinkhole) was used for ceremonial purposes, and archaeologists have recovered gold, jade, pottery, and human remains from its depths.

clues: This remote Pacific island is famous for its nearly 1,000 monumental statues called moai.
One of the most isolated inhabited islands in the world, located 3,700 kilometers from the Chilean mainland.
fun_fact: The average moai statue weighs 14 tons and stands 4 meters tall, but the largest completed statue weighs 82 tons and is 10 meters tall.
The island's native name, Rapa Nui, was given by Tahitian sailors in the 1860s; its earlier name is unknown.
trivia: Easter Island was named by Dutch explorer Jacob Roggeveen, who landed there on Easter Sunday in 1722.
The island once had a thriving civilization, but environmental degradation led to a population collapse before European contact.

clues: This archipelago off the coast of East Africa is known for its spice plantations and historic Stone Town.
Once a major center of the spice and slave trades with distinctive Swahili architecture.
fun_fact: Zanzibar briefly became an independent country after British colonial rule before joining with Tanganyika to form Tanzania.
Freddie Mercury, the lead vocalist of Queen, was born in Stone Town, Zanzibar.
trivia: Zanzibar produces about 75% of the world's cloves and is sometimes called 'Spice Island'.
Stone Town's architecture is a unique mixture of Arab, Persian, Indian, and European elements, reflecting its history as a trading hub.

clues: This medieval abbey sits atop a rocky island and is cut off from the mainland during high tide.
One of France's most recognizable landmarks, with a monastery that appears to rise from the sea.
fun_fact: Mont Saint-Michel was one of the first sites in France to be designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1979.
During the highest tides, the water around the island can rise at the speed of a galloping horse, making the causeway dangerous without proper timing.
trivia: During the Hundred Years' War, the English tried to capture Mont Saint-Michel multiple times but never succeeded, partly due to the tides.
The abbey's distinctive spire is topped with a statue of the archangel Michael striking down a dragon.

clues: This natural site features white terraces of travertine filled with mineral-rich thermal waters.
Often called 'Cotton Castle' and located near the ruins of the ancient Greco-Roman city of Hierapolis.
fun_fact: The white travertine terraces were formed by calcium-rich mineral waters flowing down the hillside and depositing calcium carbonate.
People have bathed in the thermal pools of Pamukkale for thousands of years, believing in their healing properties.
trivia: Pamukkale and the ancient city of Hierapolis together form a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Cleopatra's Pool in Hierapolis contains partially submerged ancient Roman columns, believed to have fallen during an earthquake.

clues: This island is known for its forested volcanic mountains, iconic rice paddies, and beaches.
Famous for its yoga retreats, temples, and traditional dance performances.
fun_fact: Bali follows a unique form of Hinduism called Balinese Hinduism, which combines aspects of Hinduism, Buddhism, and ancient indigenous beliefs.
The island uses a 210-day calendar system called Pawukon, alongside the Western calendar and the Islamic calendar.
trivia: Bali has a traditional irrigation system called subak that dates back to the 9th century and is recognized by UNESCO as a cultural landscape.
The island is home to over 10,000 temples, earning it the nickname 'Island of a Thousand Temples' (though there are many more).

clues: This stretch of coastline features colorful villages perched on steep cliffs above the Tyrrhenian Sea.
Known for its scenic drive along the SS163 highway with hairpin turns and dramatic views.
fun_fact: The town of Amalfi was once a maritime powerhouse with a population of 70,000 in the 11th century, but a tsunami in 1343 destroyed much of the city.
Limoncello, the famous Italian lemon liqueur, originated in this region using lemons that can grow as large as grapefruits.
trivia: The Amalfi Coast road (SS163) was built during the Napoleonic era and is considered one of the most scenic drives in the world.
The town of Ravello is known for its beautiful gardens and the annual Ravello Festival of Music.
